title-group.article-title: Beneath the surface: correlates of solitary, paired, and group living in a cryptic burrowing ghost shrimp Trypaea australiensis Dana, 1852 (Decapoda: Axiidea: Calianassidae)

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
Beneath the surface: correlates of solitary, paired, and group living in a cryptic burrowing ghost shrimp
Trypaea australiensis Dana, 1852
( Decapoda : Axiidea: Calianassidae)
Renae L. Kirby and Marian Y.L. Wong
School of Earth, Atmospheric and Life Sciences, University of Wollongong, Wollongong, NSW 2522, Australia
Correspondence:R. L.Kirby; e-mail address: 26rkirby@gmail.com

sec.title: A B ST R A CT
sec.p:
Marine organisms, particularly invertebrates, are relatively understudied regarding social structure and behaviour, especially those that are cryptic. While empirically challenging to investigate, these species can provide novel insights into the evolution of sociality given their unique ecology. Our aim was to quantify in-situ the social structure and its underlying correlates in the Australian burrowing shrimp,
Trypaea australiensis Dana, 1852
( Callianassidae ). We show that
T. australiensis
exhibits intraspecific variation in social structure, being most often found in solitary arrangements, frequently in pairs (including homosexual and heterosexual arrangements), and sometimes in groups. The majority of shrimp in pairs and groups were found in heterosexual pairings or groups of one male and multiple females. Variation in social structure was correlated with variation in body size characteristics, seasonality, and site. These findings demonstrate that a wider array of social structures are exhibited by this species than previously expected, but the obvious limitations associated with sampling a cryptic burrowing species in situ mean that further investigations under controlled conditions, including laboratory behavioural manipulations, will be needed to confirm the current findings. The use of resin casts to understand burrow morphology would be important for understanding the causes of intraspecific variation in this and other cryptic species.

sec.title: KEY WORDS: behaviour , Crustacea , cryptic species , mating system , sociality
INTRODUCTION
sec.p:
We aimed to quantify the social associations of
T. australiensis
and to investigate, in situ , the correlates of any variation in social associations. There are clear limitations of sampling within a cryptic environment, i.e., individuals residing within burrows may be missed or sampled from neighbouring burrows because of an inability to see the organisms and the burrows. Our study provides a baseline for the potential range of social associations that could be exhibited by this species.

sec.title: METHODS
sec.p: Sampling

The social structure of the burrowing shrimp
Trypaea australiensis
was studied between
September 2018 and August 2019
along the southeastern coast of New South Wales , Australia . Monthly sampling was conducted at three estuarine locations including, Maianbar at Port Hacking , Shoalhaven Heads Inlet at Shoalhaven Heads , and Garlandtown on the Moruya River ( Fig. 1 ). Each site is characterised by a sandy/muddy substratum, typical of estuarine ecosystems
.
Statistical analysis

To establish the social structure of
T. australiensis
, we first considered whether individuals occurred predominantly in solitary, paired or group associations in burrows. We used SPSS statistical software (
) and investigated whether or not burrow distributions differed significantly from that of a random distribution, using a nonparametric Chi-square goodness-of-fit test, comparing observed with Poisson distributions. A multinomial logistic regression model was conducted to assess whether the social structure was affected by site, seasonality, and morphological factors. The model contained social structure (solitary, paired or group) as a categorical response, categorical predictors of site, season, carapace length (mm) and cheliped length (mm), and burrow ID as a random factor was completed. A reference category was specified with odds ratios used to compare the odds of the response category (social structure) to the odds of each level with the predictor category site, season, carapace length and cheliped length, assuming that all predictor variables are constant.

Sexual dimorphism was investigated using a simple paired t-test comparing the cheliped length of male and female shrimp. Average cheliped length was also compared between the sexes to establish if sexual dimorphism was present. Lastly , pairs and groups were considered separately to further investigate their composition by sex and sexual maturity (this included all representative samples collected: 225 paired shrimp and 55 groups, rather than the previous analysis with a reduced data set to remove missing values as a result of missing morphological data). Summary tables were generated showing the overall trends for paired and grouped shrimp separately. Sexual maturity was determined for males and females via the values provided by
, wherein they used REGRANS relative growth models to extrapolate an inflection point (i.e., the point at which relative growth curves of juveniles and adults join) that indicates the size at which sexual maturity starts. Each pair and group were then defined as either adult-only or juveniles present (the latter referring to groups with adults and juveniles as well as juveniles-only groups). Sexual composition was categorised into three main categories for pairs: heterosexual (male/female), homosexual male (male/male), or homosexual female (female/ female) compositions. A chi-square goodness-of-fit test was conducted to determine if there were differences associated between the different sex compositions. For groups, sexual composition was classed as: all same sex, equal males and females, one female
and two or more males, one male and two or more females, or two males with three females .

sec.title: RESULTS
sec.p: Shrimp social structure

A total of 1,786 specimens of
T. australiensis
from 1,430 burrows were sampled between September 2018 and August 2019 at all three sites. After statistical cleaning, removal of samples with missing values and preliminary analysis of the data, 1,708 shrimp from 1,368 burrows were analysed to determine shrimp social structure ( Fig 2 ). The chi-square goodness-of-fit test revealed that shrimp were predominantly found in solitary arrangements (80.3% of burrows, N = 1,098), than in pairs (15.7% of burrows, N = 430), then substantially less in groups (4% of burrows, N = 180) (Chi-square goodness-of-fit, Χ 2 = 791.25, P <0.000).

When considering site, seasonality, and body size effects on the social structure of
T. australiensis
; site and season were found to have the most influence on shrimp social structure. Among sites, shrimp in paired and group associations were more likely to occur at Port Hacking and Moruya compared to Shoalhaven Heads, and solitary shrimp were more likely to occur at Shoalhaven Heads than at Port Hacking and Moruya ( Table 1 , Supplementary material Fig. S1 ). Social structure was also related to meteorological season (summer, autumn, winter, and spring). Paired shrimp were more likely to occur during the summer and spring months rather than in winter compared to solitary shrimp ( Table 1 , Supplementary material Fig. S2 ). Specifically, there were 11% more paired shrimp in the spring than in winter and 9.3% more paired than solitary shrimp in summer than in winter relative to solitary shrimp. individuals of
Trypaea australiensis
found within a particular burrow. Analyses considered effects of yearly season, site, carapace length (mm),
and cheliped length (mm) on social structure, with a random effect of burrow identification added. Reference category selected for site is

Shoalhaven Heads, and the reference category for season is winter. Bold probability values with (*) indicate statistical significance at P <0.05. Odds ratios also indicated that group arrangements were slightly more likely to occur in spring and summer months than winter when compared to paired shrimp. Furthermore, when comparing paired to solitary shrimp, there was no difference between autumn and winter ( Table 1 , Supplementary material Fig. S2 ). Body size measurements of carapace length and cheliped length showed no significant effect on social structure ( Table 1 ).
Sexual dimorphism

Of the shrimp that had claws measured, 987 were females and 721 males . The enlarged cheliped length ranged from 1.2 mm to 22.1 mm in females and 1.2 mm to 27.7 mm in males. The average enlarged cheliped length was statistically different between male and female shrimp, with males having longer cheliped lengths (mean 13.43mm ), whereas females had smaller chelipeds (mean 9.70 mm ) (t test = –114.40, df = 1707, P <0.05). There was no statistically significant difference in the mean carapace lengths of females ( 11.18 mm ) and males ( 11.30 mm ).
Sex composition in pairs

A total of 225 pairs were collected across the three sites, comprising either male/female pair ( N = 135), male/male ( N = 29), or female/ female ( N = 61) ( Table 2 ). The frequency observed for each of the sex compositions differed significantly from the expected frequencies reported (Χ2 = 76.85, P <0.001). Overall, a negative difference between observed and expected frequencies of male/ male and female/female pairings, while heterosexual pairings had a positive difference. Considering sexual maturity, pairs consisted of either two juveniles , two adults , or one adult and one juvenile . The majority of pairs collected consisted of two adults (76%), rather than pairs with one juvenile and one adult (20%), or two juveniles (4%). Trends show that heterosexual pairings occurred at higher frequencies than rather than homosexual pairings regardless of sexual maturity ( Table 2 ).
Sex composition in groups

A total of 55 groups (ranging in size from three to five individuals) were collected across the three field sites comprising either all same sex (either all male or all female), equal numbers of both sexes, one female with multiple males, one male with multiple females or two males with three females ( Fig. 3 , Table 3 ). There was a trend where more groups consisted of one male and multiple females compared to all other sex compositions except for one female and multiple male groups, with 58.3% of groups exhibiting one male with multiple females. Groups consisting of one female and multiple males contributed approximately 27.1%. Same-sex groups made up a small percentage of the groups sampled (approximately 14.6%). Groups with an even number of males and females contributed 10.4% and groups with two males and three females made up the smallest percentage of 4.2%.

Groups shared similar trends of sex composition regardless of juvenile presence. More groups comprising of all adults were found (74.5%), followed by groups with one juvenile and the rest adults (21.8%). One representative burrow comprising of only juveniles was also collected, showing one male and multiple females present. A burrow that had adults and two juveniles was also collected in a sex composition of one female and multiple males.

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p:
Trypaea australiensis
can occupy burrows either solitarily or forming social groups; i.e., paired or in small groups of up to five individuals. Although the solitary mode was dominant in the population studied, a great proportion of the total shrimp (35.7%) were found forming pairs or other associations within their respective burrows. Shrimp were mostly found as solitary individuals rather than paired or in groups. There was also a variation in the prevalence of different social structures across sites. Shrimp in paired and group associations were more likely to occur at Port Hacking and Moruya than at Shoalhaven Heads.

While the limitations of our study are apparent due to the cryptic nature of the species, our findings do suggest a greater variety of social structures are exhibited by this species than expected. To date, another burrowing shrimp,
Lepidophthalmus bocourti (A. Milne-Edwards, 1870 )
, has been found to exhibit similar facultative social arrangements (
). Therefore, the current study as well as studies by
and
represent the first key insights into burrowing shrimp social structures and provide the foundations for future work into understanding cryptic species associations.

Our study suggests that the social structure in
T. australiensis
is adaptive, linked to spatial (i.e., local factors) and temporal (i.e., breeding season) factors. This situation suggests either a facultative social structure or to the result of sampling limitations, a predominantly solitary lifestyle with temporary social interactions. The formation of pairs and groups could reflect either a temporary arrangement for reproductive reasons or possibly joint territorial defence, although further observations and experimental manipulations in controlled settings are required to verify these hypotheses. Social arrangements were also related to a range of factors, including sampling site, seasonality, and cheliped and carapace size, suggesting complex underlying reasons for the expression of different social structures. Future research into the social structure and mating system of the species would greatly benefit from the use of laboratory experiments to quantify behaviour within burrows, particularly between males and females in pairs and groups, as well as genetic analyses to quantify parentage and their mating system. Our study nevertheless provides the first detailed assessment of sociality in a highly cryptic crustacean and provides the necessary foundations for future work unravelling the social structure, behaviour, and mating systems of this and other burrowing species.
